docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 11 EXAMINATIONS AND ORDERS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 5.9, DIVISIONS 1 AND 2) [rr 11.1–11.11]

heading.title: DIVISION 11 EXAMINATIONS AND ORDERS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 5.9, DIVISIONS 1 AND 2) [rr 11.1–11.11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 11 EXAMINATIONS AND ORDERS (CORPORATIONS ACT PART 5.9, DIVISIONS 1 AND 2) [rr 11.1–11.11]

p.text: [Div 11 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
In this Division:
means a summons under section 596A or 596B of the Corporations Act for the examination of a person about a corporation’s examinable affairs.
[r 11.1 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,785.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 596A, s 596B.

An eligible applicant (ASIC, a liquidator, provisional liquidator, administrator or person authorised by ASIC) may apply for the issue of a summons to examine certain persons about a corporation’s “examinable affairs”. Section 596A of the Corporations Act provides for “mandatory examination”, where the court must issue a summons if it is satisfied that the person is an officer or provisional liquidator of the corporation during a specified period. Section 596B provides for “discretionary examination” where the court may issue a summons if it is satisfied that the person:
has taken part or been concerned in examinable affairs of the corporation and has been, or may have been, guilty of misconduct in relation to the corporation; or
may be able to give information about examinable affairs of the corporation.
Legislation cited in [15,785.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 Pt 5.9, s 596B.

The purpose of the court’s coercive power to summon a person for examination is to be gleaned from Pt 5.9 of the Corporations Act . The examination procedure is intended to aid those responsible for the external administration of a company in carrying out their duties. They are entitled only to seek an order for an examination summons where the purpose of the examination is for the benefit of the corporation, its creditors or its contributories: see further [15,785.20] . The purpose is not to disadvantage corporations (see further [15,785.25] ) but to make the corporation’s examinable officers and other persons within the contemplation of s 596B accountable to those who are obliged to act in the interests of the corporation: Re New Tel Ltd (in liq) (2005) 145 FCR 176; 221 ALR 331; [2005] FCAFC; BC200504041 at [245] [247] ; Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [17] per Santow JA. The power to issue a summons is ancillary to the exercise of judicial power: Meteyard v Love per Santow JA, above, at [46] per Basten JA, (Beazley JA at [1] agreeing).

The statutory definition of “examinable affairs” (defined in ss 9 and 53 of the Corporations Act) is very wide. Although the definition of “examinable affairs” is exhaustive in form, it is not restrictive: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [34] per Basten JA (Beazley JA agreeing at [1]). The court cautions against any a priori observations seeking to limit its scope. Matters of future intention are not necessarily beyond its scope. It will often be only when the matter is looked on in closer detail, that the court will be in any position to ascertain whether the scope of the power has been exceeded or the power abused by its use in a vexatious or oppressive manner. That may only emerge when the examination is under way, though it can emerge earlier in a clear-cut case. Information that is already known to the examiner may still be properly examinable in some circumstances (eg it may be important to know whether the third party knew of that same information at a particular time): Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [9]–[11] per Santow JA.
Legitimate purposes include:
gathering information to assist the applicant in the administration of the corporation;
identifying the corporation’s assets and liabilities;
protecting the interests of the corporation’s creditors;
enabling evidence and information to be obtained to support the bringing of proceedings against examinable officers and other persons in connection with the examinable affairs of the corporation;
facilitating the regulation of corporations by providing a public forum for the examination of examinable officers of corporations; and

obtaining information in relation to a debt owed to a creditor if such an examination would be in the interests of the corporation or its creditors as a whole: Re New Tel Ltd (in liq) (2005) 145 FCR 176; 221 ALR 331; [2005] FCAFC; BC200504041 at [252] per Lander J, Ryan and Crennan JJ concurring (application by creditor to inter alia discover knowledge of a director, who was also a partner of a law firm, and another partner of the firm who acted for the company to determine whether there was an action against the firm held not to be an improper purpose — the pool of assets to the company being larger if the ‘firm action’ were successful); Sule Arnautovic in his capacity as liquidator of Think Systems Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 787; BC200606060 at [12] (dismissed application to inspect affidavit by employees and former employees of a creditor whose proof of debt the liquidator rejected. Claim of dress rehearsal for cross-examination of witnesses in court proceedings rejected — not shown to be beyond investigating mere strengths and weaknesses of claims against company).

Other legitimate purposes include obtaining information in relation to proposed or actual litigation, in order to determine whether the defendant has sufficient assets to meet an adverse judgment, if unsuccessful in the litigation: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [44] per Basten JA, Beazley JA agreeing at [1], (seeking information relevant to a denial of liability under an insurance policy was not an impermissible purpose in the absence of showing the information might be already known or privileged) citing Re Normans Wines Ltd (rec and mgr apptd) (in liq) (2004) 88 SASR 541; 207 ALR 644; [2004] SASC 171; BC200403417 at [42] per Mullighan J (employees of auditors unsuccessful in having summons set aside. Claim rejected that the predominant purpose of the applicant liquidators was to assist a separate company in its investigations of claims against auditors in a separate action).
It is an improper purpose to use the examination:
as a dress rehearsal for cross-examination;
for the purpose of destroying the credibility of the examinees or witnesses who might be called for the examinee in substantive proceedings;
for the predominant purpose of obtaining a forensic advantage not available from ordinary pre-trial procedures; or

to obtain a forensic advantage which would not have been available to the creditor if the corporation had not gone into administration: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [44] per Basten JA (Beazley JA agreeing at [1]) (citing Re Normans Wines Ltd (rec and mgr apptd) (in liq) (2004) 88 SASR 541; 207 ALR 644; [2004] SASC 171; BC200403417 at [42] per Mullighan J; Re New Tel Ltd (in liq) (2005) 145 FCR 176; 221 ALR 331; [2005] FCAFC; BC200504041 at [252] per Lander J (Ryan and Crennan JJ concurring); Sule Arnautovic in his capacity as liquidator of Think Systems Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 787; BC200606060 at [12] ).
It is an improper purpose to use the examination:

to simply cause undue inconvenience or embarrassment to the examinee or to inflict costs: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [44]–[46] per Basten JA Beazley JA agreeing at [1];

to cause embarrassment to the examinees in a public forum and to apply pressure on them to settle favourably with a claimant: Re Bauhaus Pyrmont Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 543; BC200604082 per Austin J at [85] (held there were reasonable grounds for inferring that the liquidator applicant shared a creditor’s improper purpose of using the examination to embarrass the examinees in a public forum and to apply pressure on them to settle favourably with the creditor); or

to compel the examinee to disclose defences or to give pre-trial discovery, or to establish guilt: Hamilton v Oades (1989) 166 CLR 486 at 498 per Mason CJ (upheld finding rejecting an application to limit an examination to matters not the subject of pending criminal charges — the possibility of disclosure of a defence is not a matter in respect of which a witness needs to be protected except in exceptional cases — the power to disallow specific questions affords protection) (citing Re Hugh J Roberts Pty Ltd (in liq) [1970] 2 NSWR 582; (1970) 91 WN (NSW) 537 at 541 (the pendency of misfeasance proceedings against a director was not a sufficient basis to rescind examination orders); Huston v Costigan (1982) 45 ALR 559 at 563; 5 ALD 90 (application rejected to restrain a Royal Commissioner from receiving evidence tending to prove guilt of applicant on pending charges — adequate safeguards in place); Re Gordon (1988) 18 FCR 366; 80 ALR 289 (set aside order excusing bankrupt facing pending charges from answering certain questions on the ground that they might incriminate him — but questions to obtain evidence in proof of charge should be disallowed)).
An examination may concern itself with liability under insurance arrangements, including:
the existence of an insurance policy relating to the assets of the corporation;
the terms and conditions of such a policy;
where a claim has been made, the decision of the insurer with respect to the claim, and

where a claim has not been determined, the potential value of the claim: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [10] per Santow JA, at [36] per Basten JA (Beazley JA at [1] agreeing) (citing Re Allstate Explorations NL (2003) 46 ACSR 379; [2003] NSWSC 626; BC200303775 per Austin J; Re Clutha Ltd (in liq) (2003) 44 ACSR 73; 421 ACLC 1232; [2003] NSWSC 235; BC200301322 per Gzell J).

Where a decision has been made and communicated, the internal assessment of information by advisers to the insurer are not “examinable affairs” even though the result of that assessment may be relevant to the decision taken by the insurer and hence to the value and even the solvency of the company: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [43] per Basten JA (Beazley JA at [1] agreeing). “Examinable affairs” includes information relevant to the decision whether to institute proceedings against an insurer in relation to the denial of liability under the insurance policy such as information necessary to assess the justification or otherwise of the denial and in an appropriate case information as to the worth of the potential defendant in such proceedings: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [47] per Basten JA (Beazley JA agreeing at [1]) (citing Re BPTC Ltd (in liq) (1994) 14 ACSR 460 at 462; BC9403006 , Re Hugh J Roberts Pty Ltd (in liq) [1970] 2 NSWR 582; (1970) 91 WN (NSW) 537 at 541 and Grosvenor Hill (Qld) Pty Ltd v Barber (1994) 48 FCR 301 at 309; 120 ALR 262 at 270; 12 ACSR 646 at 654 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,790] r 11.2 Application for examination or investigation under s 411(9)(b), s 423 or s 536(3) of the Corporations Act

leg:heading.title: Application for examination or investigation under s 411(9)(b) , s 423 or s 536(3) of the Corporations Act

p.text: An application for an order for the examination or investigation of a person under section 411(9)(b) , section 423 or subsection 536(3) of the Corporations Act may be made by:
ASIC; or
a person authorised by ASIC; or
a creditor or contributory; or
any other person aggrieved by the conduct of:
a person appointed to administer a compromise or arrangement; or
a controller; or
a liquidator or provisional liquidator.
[subr (1) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
The application may be made without notice to any person.
[subr (2) subst Gaz 93 of 1 June 2001 p 3023]

The provisions of this Division that apply to an examination under Division 1 of Part 5.9 of the Corporations Act apply, with any necessary adaptations, to an examination or an investigation under section 411(9)(b) , section 423 or subsection 536(3) of the Corporations Act.
[subr (3) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
[r 11.2 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,795] r 11.3 Application for examination summons (Corporations Act s 596A, s 596B) — Form 17

leg:heading.title: Application for examination summons (Corporations Act s 596A , s 596B ) — Form 17

p.text: An application for the issue of an examination summons must be made by filing an interlocutory process or an originating process, as the case requires.
The application may be made without notice to any person.
[subr (2) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; subst Gaz 93 of 1 June 2001 p 3023]
The originating process, or interlocutory process, seeking the issue of the examination summons must be:
supported by an affidavit stating the facts in support of the process; and
accompanied by a draft examination summons.
The originating process, or interlocutory process, and supporting affidavit must be filed in a sealed envelope marked, as appropriate:
“Application and supporting affidavit for issue of summons for examination under section 596A of the Corporations Act 2001”; or
“Application and supporting affidavit for issue of summons for examination under section 596B of the Corporations Act 2001”.
[subr (4) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

If the application is not made by the liquidator, the liquidator must be given notice of the application and, if required by the liquidator, served with a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, and the supporting affidavit.

If the application is not made by ASIC, ASIC must be given notice of the application and, if required by ASIC, served with a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, and the supporting affidavit.
[subr (6) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
Unless the Court otherwise orders, an affidavit in support of an application for an examination summons is not available for inspection by any person.
An examination summons must be in accordance with Form 17 .
[subr (8) am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608]
[r 11.3 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,795.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 596B, s 596C(2).

Examinees may seek an order under s 596C(2) of the Corporations Act permitting them to inspect the affidavit sworn in support of an application for the issue of examination summonses under s 596B . Access is not given unless the Court “otherwise orders”: r 11.3(7). An applicant for inspection will generally be able to obtain access to the affidavit if he or she can demonstrate an arguable case that the issue of the summons exceeded the power of the court under s 596B and that access to the affidavit is likely to assist in determining the correctness of the challenge: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [141] per Basten JA.

However, there are sound reasons why inspection, though prima facie to be allowed, should not be freely granted, “for so to do could afford an examinee information which could permit the examination process to be frustrated”, and could disclose confidential information that should properly be withheld: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec & mgrs apptd) (in liq), (2006) 58 ACSR 113; [2006] NSWSC 184; BC200604947 at [104] per Austin J citing Re Excel Finance Corporation Ltd (rec & mgr apptd); Worthley v England (1994) 52 FCR 69; 124 ALR 281; 14 ACSR 407 at 429 . The court must be conscious of the possibility that an examination might nevertheless proceed and that access by an examinee to the affidavit may compromise that process: Sule Arnautovic in his capacity as liquidator of Think Systems Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 787; BC200606060 at [4] per Barrett J.
Legislation cited in [15,795.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 596D(2), s 9.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 68.

A person served with a summons may be required to produce, at the examination, specified books: s 596D(2) of the Corporations Act. The term “books” is defined in s 9 . This includes a register, financial reports or financial records, however compiled, recorded or stored; and any other record of information. Orders for production of documents are not usually included in the examination summonses but made separately pursuant to CPA s 68 (formerly the power under SCR Pt 36 r 12 was used. It is now repealed).

level.toc-caption: [15,795.15] Leave to be heard on application for issue of summons

p.text: Legislation cited in [15,795.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 11.3(2), 11.5(2), r 2.13.

heading.title: Leave to be heard on application for issue of summons

p.text: Usually the application for the issue of an examination summons is ex parte and, if a summons is issued, the person summoned may apply to the court within three days after being served for an order discharging the summons: UCPR rr 11.3(2) , 11.5(2) . Pursuant to UCPR r 2.13 (1) the court may grant leave to the prospective examinee to be heard on the application for the issue of examination summons: Onefone Australia Pty Ltd v One.Tel Ltd [2007] NSWSC 69; BC200700556 at [40]–[42] per Barrett J, 14 February 2007 (the application for leave was entertained and dismissed. No express decision was made as to whether special circumstances were required to justify departure from the usual procedure).

An examination summons issued by the Court must be personally served, or served in any other manner as the Court may direct, on the person who is to be examined at least 8 days before the date fixed for the examination.
Legislation cited in [15,800.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 [r 10.14].
Substituted service of an examination order may be ordered under UCPR [r 10.14] if personal service is impractical.
Legislation cited in [15,800.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 27.

An examination order under may be served interstate under s 27 of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) without any leave being necessary: Re Austral Oil Estates Ltd (in liq) (1986) 7 NSWLR 440; 86 FLR 247; BC8600466 ; cf Re Tropical Reef Enterprises Pty Ltd (in liq) (1987) 11 ACLR 413; 5 ACLC 95.
Legislation cited in [15,800.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.5.

Pursuant to UCPR r 11.5 , leave to serve outside Australia an examination summons under s 596A Corporations Act 2001 may be given on the basis that the summons itself as distinct from the application for the summons is not an originating process: Application of Robert William Whitton [2007] NSWSC 606; BC200704487 at [4]–[10] per White J (leave given to serve summons in USA).
This rule applies if a person is served with an examination summons.
Within 3 days after the person is served with the examination summons, the person may apply to the Court for an order discharging the summons by filing:
an interlocutory process seeking an order discharging the summons; and
an affidavit stating the facts in support of the interlocutory process.

As soon as practicable after filing the interlocutory process seeking the order and the supporting affidavit, the person must serve a copy of the interlocutory process and the supporting affidavit on:
the person who applied for the examination; and
unless that person is ASIC or a person authorised by ASIC — ASIC.
[subr (3) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
Legislation cited in [15,805.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 49.19.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 121(3).
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 596B.

Where the issue of the summons has been ordered by a registrar (the usual case), an application for discharge is governed by the principles that apply to challenges to decisions of registrars, namely UCPR r 49.19 and Supreme Court Act 1970 s 121(3) : Re Wily; LED (South Coast) Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 946; BC200908305 at [4]–[25] per Barrett J (rejecting a submission that federal review procedures were applicable), citing Gordon v Tolcher (2006) 231 CLR 334; 231 ALR 582; [2006] HCA 62; BC200610441 ; Tomko v Palasty (No 2) (2007) 71 NSWLR 61; [2007] NSWCA 369; BC200710980 at [7], [8], [52] . In substance a proceeding to discharge the issue of such a summons involves a re-hearing of the initial application: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [31] per Basten JA, (Beazley JA at [1] agreeing) (citing Gerah Imports Pty Ltd v The Duke Group Ltd (in liq) (1993) 61 SASR 557; 116 FLR 479; (1993) 12 ACSR 513 at 517 per Olsson J (King CJ and Millhouse J agreeing)). A person seeking to set aside an examination summons must show that there is an arguable case that the issue of the summons exceeded the court’s power under Corporations Act 2001 s 596B . If the person wants the liquidator to reveal the content of the s 596C(1) affidavit, they must show that access to the affidavit is likely to assist in determining the correctness of the decision to issue the summons: Re Wily; LED (South Coast) Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 946; BC200908305 at [27]–[29] , citing Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [140]–[141] ; Ariff v Fong (2007) 63 ACSR 384; [2007] NSWCA 183; BC200705734 at [25]–[26] .
Legislation cited in [15,805.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 596B, 596D.

The court has jurisdiction to set aside examination proceedings initiated for an improper purpose: Re Excel Finance Corporation Ltd (rec & mgr apptd); Worthley v England (1994) 52 FCR 69; 124 ALR 281; 14 ACSR 407 . As to permissible and non-permissible purposes see notes to [15,785] . The question whether in any particular case the applicant has used the procedure abusively will depend upon the applicant’s purpose in seeking the order and all of the surrounding circumstances. It will not be an abuse unless an offensive purpose is at least the predominant purpose. It will be an offensive purpose if the application cannot be characterised as being for the benefit of the corporation, its contributories or creditors: Re New Tel Ltd (in liq) (2005) 145 FCR 176; 221 ALR 331; [2005] FCAFC; BC200504041 at [252] per Lander J (Ryan and Crennan JJ concurring); Sule Arnautovic in his capacity as liquidator of Think Systems Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 787; BC200606060 at [12] . The court retains a power to give directions and to restrain questions in cases where the examination is being conducted for an improper purpose or constitutes an abuse of process: Meteyard v Love (2005) 65 NSWLR 36; 224 ALR 588; [2005] NSWCA 444; BC200510880 at [8], [12] per Santow JA.

The fact that an applicant has offered numerous documents for inspection by the liquidator and that a director has offered to and has met with the liquidator to discuss relevant matters does not per se constitute a basis for setting aside a summons. A liquidator is not obliged to proceed in an informal manner and may properly exercise the powers under ss 596B and 596D of the Corporations Act and the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules in order to obtain evidence on oath or affirmation for a proper purpose and to ensure that all documents are produced in a manner which informal production cannot guarantee: Re Coral Resorts Pty Ltd (in liq) [2012] NSWSC 560; BC201203717 at [7] per Black J (offer of production and discussion not sufficient to set aside summons).
Legislation cited in [15,805.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 11.5(2).

An application for an order discharging an examination summons is to be made within three days after the summons is served: Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 11.5(2) . However, the time limit in r 11.5(2) may be extended under the rules of court to extend time: Re Bridgeport — Advisers & Asset Managers Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 146; [2005] NSWSC 757; BC200505700 at [7]–[11] per Barrett J (summons filed 3 weeks after service of summons).

The subsequent availability of the affidavit in support to the examinee does not lessen the liquidator's duty of disclosure. Non-disclosure in the supporting affidavit of matters material to the decision of the Registrar to issue a summons for examination might result in the summons being set aside. Relevant factors to the exercise of the discretion include whether, had the matters been disclosed, the decision would have been the same and whether the non-disclosure came about through an error of judgment as to the materiality of the matters not disclosed. Where a summons is set aside, the discharge of the summons is not a bar to the applicant making a fresh application on an affidavit which makes full disclosure of all material matters: Re Mendarma Pty Ltd (in liq) [2006] NSWSC 1306; BC200610137 at [46], [58]–[59] per White J (material non-disclosure of pendency of Equity proceedings — summonses set aside).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,810] r 11.6 Filing of record of examination (Corporations Act s 597(13))

leg:heading.title: Filing of record of examination (Corporations Act s 597(13) )

p.text: If the Court makes an order in relation to an examination under subsection 597(13) of the Corporations Act, the Court may give directions for the filing of the written record of the examination.
[r 11.6 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,810.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 597(13), s 597(5A).

By s 597(13) Corporations Act 2001, the court may order the questions put to a person and the answers given by him or her at an examination to be recorded in writing and may require him or her to sign that written record. Because of the different rules, as to rights of inspection, applicable to different forms of written records of Pt 5.9 examinations and the discretionary nature of s 597(13), it is desirable that the judicial officer presiding at an examination should, at the outset, invite submissions as to appropriate orders and directions on those matters from the examinee, the person upon whose application the examination summons was issued and any person who exercises the s 597(5A) right to take part in the examination. Explicit orders and directions should be made in the light of any such submissions and in a way that leaves no doubt about the status of any transcript or record for the purposes of the relevant statutory provisions. However, the finding that an order has been made may be implied from an indication that the proceedings are being tape recorded which will later be transcribed and that the examinee is to sign the written record in fact brought into existence. A “request for transcript” sent by the Deputy Registrar to the Court Reporting Service is not an “order” for s 597(13) purposes: Strarch Int Pty Ltd (in liq) v Loh (2005) 219 ALR 547; 54 ACSR 481; [2005] NSWSC 769; BC200505709 at [17] [28] per Barrett J.
Legislation cited in [15,810.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

Section 597 of the Corporations Act 2001 contemplates two different forms of document recording proceedings at an examination (see s 597(14) ). The first is a “written record of an examination so signed by a person” ( s 597(13) ). The second is a “transcript of an examination of a person that is authenticated as provided by the rules”. The legislation does not preclude the possibility of a document recording proceedings that falls outside both those descriptions. A document within the first description is, by s 597(14A) , available for inspection by any person (subject to payment of a fee if the person is not within s 597(14A)(a) ) and that the right of inspection under s 597(14A) cannot be abrogated by a direction under s 596F(1)(e) : Strarch Int Pty Ltd (in liq) v Loh (2005) 219 ALR 547; 54 ACSR 481; [2005] NSWSC 769; BC200505709 per Barrett J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,815] r 11.7 Authentication of transcript of examination (Corporations Act s 597(14))

leg:heading.title: Authentication of transcript of examination (Corporations Act s 597(14) )

p.text: For the purposes of subsection 597(14) of the Corporations Act, a transcript of an examination may be authenticated:

by the person, or persons, who prepared the record of examination, or under whose supervision the record was prepared, certifying in writing signed by the person or persons, that the record is a true transcript of the record of examination; or

by any person present at the examination, or any part of the examination, signing the person’s name at the bottom of each page of the written record that records a part of the examination at which the person was present.
[r 11.7 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,820] r 11.8 Inspection of record or transcript of examination or investigation under s 411, s 423 or s 536 of the Corporations Act

leg:heading.title: Inspection of record or transcript of examination or investigation under s 411 , s 423 or s 536 of the Corporations Act

p.text: A written record or transcript of an examination or investigation under section 411 , 423 or 536 is not available for inspection by any person except:
with the consent of the liquidator (if any) or ASIC; or
by leave of the Court.
[subr (1) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
This rule does not apply to the liquidator, ASIC or any person authorised by ASIC.
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 11.8 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,825] r 11.9 Entitlement to record or transcript of examination held in public

leg:heading.title: Entitlement to record or transcript of examination held in public

p.text: This rule applies if:
an examination under section 597 of the Corporations Act is held wholly or partly in public; and
a written record or transcript of the examination is filed in the Court.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

The person examined may apply to the Registrar, within 3 years after the date of completion of the examination, for a copy of the record or transcript of the part of the examination of the person held in public.
On receiving an application from a person under subrule (2) , and any applicable fee, the Registrar must give a copy of the record or transcript to the person.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,830] r 11.10 Default in relation to examination

p.text: This rule applies if a person is summoned or ordered by the Court to attend for examination, and:
without reasonable cause, the person:
fails to attend at the time and place appointed; or
fails to attend from day to day until the conclusion of the examination; or
refuses or fails to take an oath or make an affirmation; or
refuses or fails to answer a question that the Court directs the person to answer; or
refuses or fails to produce books that the summons requires the person to produce; or
fails to comply with a requirement by the Court to sign a written record of the examination; or

before the day fixed for the examination, the person who applied for the summons or order satisfies the Court that there is reason to believe that the person summoned or ordered to attend for examination has absconded or is about to abscond.
The Court may:
issue a warrant for the arrest of the person summoned or ordered to attend for examination; and
make any other orders that the Court thinks just or necessary.
Legislation cited in [15,830.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 subr (2)(a).

The authority to issue a warrant for the arrest of the person summoned conferred by subr (2)(a) depends on proof: first, that the person has been summoned or ordered by the court to attend for examination; secondly, that the person has (relevantly) failed to attend at the time and place appointed, or failed to attend from day to day until the conclusion of the examination; and, thirdly, has done so without reasonable cause: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [34] per Brereton J.
Legislation cited in [15,830.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 97, s 97(2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 38.6.

The Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 make no specific provision for the procedure on application for issue of a warrant under r 11.10. Rule 11.10 is an independent source of power to issue a warrant, not dependent upon CPA s 97 ; but procedures applicable under s 97 (and previously under former SCR Pt 42 r 7) provide some guidance, at least by analogy, with the exception that UCPR r 38.6 does not apply. While r 11.10 does not explicitly provide that an order under that rule may be made ex parte, semble by analogy to s 97(2) CPA and the issue of bench warrants the application may be ex parte: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [37], [38], [47] per Brereton J.

The term “at the time and place appointed” should not be construed too narrowly and where by arrangement between the liquidator and the examinee, another date was substituted for the time and place originally appointed, that will be the relevant date. Alternatively, if no date is substituted, but the listing is adjourned, failure to attend on the adjourned date may constitute a failure to attend “from day to day until the conclusion of the examination”: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [42] per Brereton J.

Semble the liquidator bears the onus of negativing reasonable cause. However, since knowledge of the cause is in the possession almost exclusively of the examinees, relatively slight evidence would be required to discharge that onus. Where steps have been taken, by letter and telephone, to warn the examinees’ solicitor of the imperative that the examinees attend, and of the consequences should they fail to do so, and failure to respond to such requests or assertions that the examinees were “not available”, or at the highest “had some urgent business to attend to” may suffice to negative reasonable cause. Responses given by the examinees during any partially completed examination might also be relevant: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [44] per Brereton J.
Although the conditions for issue of a warrant might be satisfied, the decision to issue a warrant remains a discretionary one. Relevant discretionary considerations include
the prima facie entitlement of a person who has procured the issue of a subpoena or examinations summons which has not been set aside to have it complied with and, if not, enforced;
the importance of securing compliance with orders of the court intended to enable relevant evidence or information to be obtained in the interests of justice;
the reasonableness of steps already taken to obtain the co-operative attendance of the examinee or witness and the possibility of securing attendance by less extreme means; and
whether the burden imposed by the subpoena or summons is prima facie oppressive: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [45] per Brereton J.

By analogy with a bench warrant in the case of a witness who fails to attend a trial in answer to a subpoena, the appropriate course would ordinarily be to secure the attendance of the examinee at court at the earliest possible date so that the examination may proceed. It is not necessary to defer the issue of the warrant or order that it should lie in the Registry for some time before execution. There is no necessity for the form of warrant for arrest to contain provision for the examinee to avoid being taken into custody by paying a sum of money into court as security for his or her appearance. The court may direct service of notice of the order for issue of the warrant on the examinees’ solicitor so that the examinees may apply for discharge of the order if so advised: Struthers (in his capacity as liquidator) of PACI Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 864; BC200506404 at [48]–[50] per Brereton J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,835] r 11.11 Service of application for order in relation to breaches etc by person concerned with corporation (Corporations Act s 598)

leg:heading.title: Service of application for order in relation to breaches etc by person concerned with corporation (Corporations Act s 598 )

p.text: This rule applies to a person applying for an order under section 598 of the Corporations Act.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

In addition to complying with rules 2.7 and 2.8 , the person must serve a copy of the originating process, or interlocutory process, as the case requires, and the supporting affidavit on any liquidator or provisional liquidator (except if the person is the liquidator or provisional liquidator) of the corporation or body.

Under rule 2.7 , a plaintiff must serve a copy of the originating process, and any supporting affidavit, on a defendant to the proceeding and, if necessary, on the corporation to which the proceeding relates; and an applicant must serve a copy of an interlocutory process, and any supporting affidavit, on a respondent to the proceeding and, if necessary, on the corporation to which the proceeding relates. In certain cases, these documents may also be required to be served on ASIC — see rule 2.8 .
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 11.11 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
